title: How to water your freaking plants so they don't die after one week
author: Mellissa Bail

sections.content: The first step to watering your plants properly is to know what type of plant you have. Different plants have different water requirements, so it's important to research your plant's specific needs. Some plants prefer to dry out completely between watering, while others need to be kept consistently moist. Make sure you understand your plant's preferences before you start watering.

Before you water your plant, it's important to check the soil moisture level. Stick your finger into the soil up to the second knuckle â€“ if it feels dry, it's time to water. If it feels moist, wait a few days and check again. Overwatering can be just as harmful as underwatering, so it's important not to water your plants too frequently.

When you're ready to water your plant, make sure you do it correctly. Water your plant thoroughly until water begins to drain out of the bottom of the pot. This ensures that the roots receive enough water and also helps to flush out any excess salts or minerals in the soil. If your plant is in a decorative container without drainage holes, make sure to remove any excess water from the saucer after watering to prevent the roots from sitting in water.

The environment your plant is in can affect its watering needs. Plants in bright, sunny areas may need to be watered more frequently than those in low-light areas. Similarly, plants in air-conditioned or heated rooms may need more water than those in more temperate environments. Be aware of your plant's surroundings and adjust your watering schedule accordingly.

Finally, don't forget to fertilize your plants. While watering is important, fertilizing provides your plants with the nutrients they need to thrive. Follow the instructions on your fertilizer package and fertilize your plants according to their specific needs. This will help keep your plants healthy and vibrant.

title: How to repot a Monstera without killing it and foster its growth
author: Jesse Rowe

sections.sectiontitle: Why should you repot your Monstera?
sections.content: As your Monstera grows, its roots need more space to spread out and absorb water and nutrients. If it becomes root-bound, which means the roots have filled the container and have nowhere else to grow, it can lead to stunted growth and root rot. Repotting your Monstera will give it the room it needs to thrive.

sections.sectiontitle: When should you repot your Monstera?
sections.content: The ideal time to repot your Monstera is in the spring or early summer, when it's actively growing. However, if you notice signs of stress, such as slowed growth or root-bound roots, it's time to repot.

sections.sectiontitle: Choosing the right pot and soil
sections.content: When repotting your Monstera, choose a pot that's one size larger than the current one. A good rule of thumb is to select a pot that's 2-3 inches wider. Your Monstera will appreciate a well-draining potting mix that's rich in organic matter, like a mixture of peat moss, perlite, and vermiculite. You can also add orchid bark or charcoal to the mix to aid in drainage and aeration.

Before repotting, water your Monstera a day or two ahead of time. This will help the soil hold together and reduce stress on the roots. You can also gently loosen the roots from the soil to help them adjust to their new home.

Here are the steps to follow when repotting your Monstera. Firstly gently remove the Monstera from its current pot by tapping the sides and pulling it out. If it's stuck, you can carefully slide a knife or trowel along the inside of the pot to loosen it. Once you've removed the plant from the pot, gently tease the roots apart and remove any dead or damaged roots. Be careful not to damage the healthy roots. Place the Monstera in the new pot, making sure the top of the root ball is level with the top of the potting mix. You can also add a bamboo stake or trellis to support the plant as it grows. Fill in the gaps around the root ball with more potting mix, making sure to gently press down to remove any air pockets. Water the plant thoroughly and let it drain. You can also add a layer of mulch or moss on top of the soil to help retain moisture.

After repotting, care for your Monstera as you normally would, ensuring it receives adequate light, water, and nutrients. With proper care, your Monstera should thrive in its new home. Repotting may seem intimidating, but with these simple steps, you can successfully repot your Monstera without harming it and help foster its growth.
